attachments.title: This Is Why There Are So Many Ties In Swimming
attachments.text: Tonight three legends of swimming—Michael Phelps, Chad Le Clos, and László Cseh—turned in identical times to share silver in the 100m butterfly. Last night, Simone Manuel tied for gold with Canadian Penny Oleksiak in the 100m freestyle. Modern timing systems are capable of measuring down to the millionth of a second—so why doesn’t FINA, the world swimming governing body, increase its timing precision by adding thousandths-of-seconds?
attachments.fallback: Regressing: This Is Why There Are So Many Ties In Swimming

text: thermal expansion of concrete is 5.5 millionths per degree F
so 164 foot pool would expand 0.054 inches given a 5 degree F rise in temp
but seems like they could engineer it with similar cross section for each lane so each lane expands and contracts evenly
also they could have adjustable stops at the end that are adjusted dynamically based on conditions
